questions.text: Which of the Brodmann areas is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brodmann area 6 corresponds to the premotor cortex, not the primary motor cortex. The primary motor cortex is Brodmann area 4.

questions.text: Which function has the least role in Heschl's gyrus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Heschl's gyrus mainly handles primary auditory input and plays little to no role in higher-level comprehension.

  • Heschl's gyrus corresponds to Brodmann areas 41 and 42.
  • Receives auditory input via fibres from the medial geniculate body through the auditory radiation.
  • Involved in the initial perception and processing of sounds, especially tone and frequency.
  • Plays a supportive role in phonologic tasks and auditory feedback during speech.
  • Comprehension, however, is primarily managed by Wernicke's area and adjacent multimodal association cortices.
  • This area is not only important for language comprehension, but more importantly, it has a crucial role in speech production, phonologic retrieval, and semantic processing.
  • Heschl's gyrus is a major component of the posterior portion of the superior temporal gyrus (STG) and forms the anatomical substrate of the primary auditory area.

Explanation of Other Options:

Language comprehension (Option A): Heschl's gyrus provides auditory input necessary for Wernicke's area to interpret language.

Speech production (Option B): It assists through auditory monitoring and feedback mechanisms.

Phonologic retrieval (Option C): Participates by processing and relaying auditory cues important for phoneme recognition.

questions.text: Identify the marked cranial nerve:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fourth cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem, specifically below the inferior colliculus of the midbrain.

  • It is the only cranial nerve to emerge dorsally, which helps in its unique identification in dorsal brainstem images.
  • The trochlear nerve emerges below the inferior colliculi on the dorsal midbrain.
  • It innervates the superior oblique muscle, causing depression and intorsion of the eye.
  • It has the longest intracranial course and is also the thinnest cranial nerve.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cranial nerve 6 (Option B): Emerges from the ventral brainstem at the pontomedullary junction; it supplies the lateral rectus muscle for eye abduction. It is not dorsal in origin.

Cranial nerve 5 (Option C): Emerges from the lateral aspect of the pons; it's the largest cranial nerve and carries both sensory and motor fibres. Not seen in this dorsal view.

Cranial nerve 3 (Option D): Emerges from the ventral midbrain, between the cerebral peduncles, and supplies most of the extraocular muscles; not visible from the dorsal side.

questions.text: The elevation of the facial colliculus is due to which structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The facial colliculus is formed by the underlying abducens nucleus (CN VI), around which the motor fibres of the facial nerve (CN VII) loop dorsally, producing this surface elevation.

  • The facial colliculus is a unique feature located in the pons that houses the abducens nucleus and the facial motor fibres.
  • This distinctive interaction between the two cranial nerves leads to multi-level neurological dysfunctions when there is a lesion of the facial colliculus.
  • The facial colliculus is an elevation on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the pons under which is located the abducens nucleus (cranial nerve VI) and the axons of the facial nerve nucleus (VII), which arc around the abducens nucleus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Facial nucleus (Option A): Located in the ventrolateral pons; it contributes to the colliculus only via its fibres, not the nucleus itself.

Vestibulocochlear nucleus (Option C): Located laterally in the pons-medulla junction; not involved in colliculus formation.

Hypoglossal nucleus (Option D): Found in the medulla near the floor of the 4th ventricle; forms the hypoglossal trigone, not the facial colliculus.

questions.text: Which branch of the facial nerve is responsible for supplying the muscles of facial expression?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Branchial motor fibres of the facial nerve innervate the muscles of facial expression and other branchial arch-derived muscles.

  • Branchial motor fibres (special visceral efferent):
    • Supply the muscles of facial expression
    • Also innervate: posterior belly of digastric, stylohyoid, stapedius

Cranial nerve seven (CN VII) is responsible for both efferent and afferent modalities in the head and neck, including:

  1. Branchial motor fibres that innervate:
  2. muscles of "facial expression"
  3. stylohyoid muscle
  4. posterior belly of the digastric
  5. stapedius
  6. occipitofrontalis
  7. Special sensory fibres for taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue
  8. General sensation from the external auditory canal and auricle
  9. Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres innervating the submandibular, sublingual, lacrimal glands, as well as the mucous membranes of the nose, palate, and oropharynx

Explanation of Other Options:

Special sensory (Option A): Carries taste, not motor function; from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue.

General sensory (Option B): Supplies cutaneous sensation to part of the external auditory canal and auricle.

Paraganglionic parasympathetic (Option D): Controls salivation and lacrimation, not facial movement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows the interpeduncular fossa, a midline depression on the ventral surface of the midbrain between the cerebral peduncles. Important neuroanatomical structures that appear in this region include:

  • Tuber cinereum (Option C):
    • Grey matter elevation of the hypothalamus.
    • Located anterior to the mammillary bodies and continuous with the infundibulum of the pituitary gland.
  • Mammillary bodies (Option A):
    • The round paired hypothalamic structures are involved in the limbic system (memory pathway).
    • Located posterior to the tuber cinereum.
  • Posterior perforated substance (Option B):
    • Lies between the cerebral peduncles.
    • Contains small openings for perforating arteries supplying the midbrain and thalamus.
  • Oculomotor nerves (CN III):
    • Emerge from the medial aspect of the cerebral peduncles in the interpeduncular fossa.

questions.text: Which structure does not contain efferent autonomic nerve fibres?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dorsal root of a spinal nerve contains afferent sensory nerve fibres and no efferent autonomic nerve fibres.

  • The efferent autonomic nerve fibres, which originate in the lateral horn of the spinal nerve, travel out of the spinal cord through the ventral root of the spinal nerve.
  • As the ventral and dorsal roots join to form the spinal nerve, the fibres from both roots intermingle, and the dorsal and ventral primary rami take a mix of fibres, including afferent sensory fibres from the dorsal root and efferent motor fibres from the ventral root.
  • Postganglionic sympathetic efferent fibres join each spinal nerve via a grey ramus communicans. So, all of the other nerves listed do contain efferent autonomic fibres.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dorsal ramus of C4 (Option A): Contains mixed fibres, including postganglionic sympathetic efferents.

Ventral root of T3 (Option C): Contains preganglionic autonomic efferents originating from the lateral horn.

Ventral ramus of L2 (Option D): Contains both somatic and autonomic fibres, including sympathetic efferents from the sympathetic trunk.

questions.text: Which muscle is innervated by the posterior primary rami?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Of all the answer choices, erector spinae is the only true back muscle listed.

  • True back muscles act on the vertebral column, producing its movements and maintaining posture.
  • These true back muscles are innervated by posterior (dorsal) primary rami.
  • The other four muscles are superficial back muscles that aid with the movements of the limbs as well as with respiration.
  • They mostly receive their nerve supply from the ventral rami of cervical nerves.
  • The latissimus dorsi is innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve, which is made from branches of the ventral primary rami of C5 and C6. (Option A)
  • Levator scapulae and rhomboideus major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve, a branch of the ventral primary rami of C5. (The superior part of levator scapulae also receives some innervation from the ventral primary rami of C3 and C4). (Option B, C)
  • Lastly, the trapezius is innervated by the accessory nerve (CN XI) but also receives innervation from C3 and C4 ventral primary rami for proprioception.
